awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: A Parallel Computing Engine for Simulation of Complex Multi-Scale Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this PFI project stems from the development of an inexpensive, highly parallel computing platform to solve scientific and engineering simulations while taking advantage of the front end and post-processing tools of commercially available finite-element software. The breakthrough scientific and commercial opportunity stems from the use of parallel computing hardware developed in recent years in support of the computer gaming industry, that has not been leveraged yet for solution of simulation problems currently addressed using finite element methods. This can lead to a breakthrough in the simulation industry by embracing an approach to the solution of boundary value problems that does not require inversion of large matrices. The proposed approach will benefit several scientific and engineering applications where large dimensions or multi-scale geometries makes meshing computationally prohibitive, and addresses critical bottlenecks in engineering design and simulation, in particular in transient analysis and design optimization. The potential business opportunity is significant: the successful adoption of the proposed approach would lead to a major breakthrough in the performance of software for engineering and scientific simulation, while exploiting newly available parallel computing resources (gaming graphics engines).


The proposed project supports the development of an inexpensive, highly parallel simulation platform that can be integrated with pre and post processing tools of existing finite-element software. The proposed module will be implemented using gaming graphics processors, enabling a breakthrough speed-up in simulation time compared to conventional finite element software. The final deliverables will be presented to potential partners or investors for commercialization and future development. Interviews with engineers and scientists under an NSF I-Corps study revealed a significant need and interest for simulation tools that address the bottlenecks of existing finite-element tools, in particular in terms of prohibitively long simulation times. The proposed project is transformative for the following reasons: (i) A novel approach for the simulation of complex systems using highly-parallel computing is proposed, (ii) the proposed approach can lead to a breakthrough reduction in simulation time compared to available software in large scale problems and transient analyses, and (iii) the proposed approach will lead to a simulation engine that can be integrated with pre and post processing tools from existing finite element method (FEM) software, enabling its use within well developed products that already have a solid customer base.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Finite element methods (FEM) are universally accepted tools for engineering analysis of physical systems described by partial differential equations in a 3D spatial domain. Highly sophisticated FEM tools are currently available, however:

  • Multi-scale multi-physics systems lead to very large number of elements and impractical simulation times, particularly in transient simulations.
  • Conventional FEM is not well posed for parallelization. Available FEM software does not support state of the art computing engines (such as GPUs, graphics processing units).
  • Most end users use similar software tools, therefore their limitations are accepted as ?normal?.
  • Engineering analysis and product development has long been done with tools that are not optimal, therefore the motivation to change is not strong in most companies.

Monte-Carlo Methods (MCM) have breakthrough potential in the finite-element engineering and analysis market, via mesh-free operation and extensive parallelization based on the use of GPUs (graphics processing units). This project proposed the development of a novel computational engine for the simulation of multi-scale systems where proper meshing by conventional finite element methods becomes prohibitive. The proposed engine, based on Monte Carlo methods, enables spatial and dynamic simulation of systems with multi-scale geometries that are intractable by conventional finite elements tools, such as transient heat transfer in large systems with temperature-dependent properties, and is highly amenable to parallelization.

Taking full advantage of GPU computing makes MCM a promising approach to achieve a breakthrough in simulation time of multi-scale systems and transient analysis of spatial and multi-physics systems.

The target market space is a subset of users in the finite element software market, which is estimated in excess of $1 billion as of 2017. The target audience consists of (i) users with simulation problems that cannot be properly addressed with currently available software tools, (ii) users that are forced to use significant approximations to save simulation time using currently existing tools, that would prefer more accurate results with reasonable execution time, (iii) users that would like to use finite element tools for design optimization but are not able to do so due to impractical simulation times. It is likely that more users and applications would appear if simulation times with current tools were not prohibitive in some scientific and engineering problems.

The primary objective of the project was to develop and demonstrate a solver-engine for multi-scale multi-physics problems based on a highly parallelizable numerical method based on the Monte-Carlo approach. The solver-engine is ideally compatible with preprocessor and postprocessor tools of available numerical simulation commercial software currently in the market. The parallelizability of the proposed method can reduce the simulation-time considerably while the accuracy of the process is benchmarked against other numerical approaches such as existing finite element software and/or available experimental results. 

The solver engine demonstrations developed with support of this PFI grant are proof-of concept demonstrations and were used to attract participation/partnership with existing finite element software companies for future development - to find a path for commercialization of the proposed tools within existing software products with well-established customer bases and distribution networks. The demos developed were also used to engage potential industrial partners that have engineering analysis problems that are not well suited for existing finite element tools.

A prototype multi-GPU engine that enables execution of the MCM solver described above was succefully completed and tested under support from this grant. The system enables the solution of selected boundary value problems in a highly parallel, scalable, state-of-the-art computing platform, with a corresponding breakthrough in simulation time compared to current solvers. Benchmark tests on the multi-GPU platform showed 35 times faster simulation times compared to multi-CPU-based simulation, and 120 times faster simulation times compared to state of the art finite element commercial software. 

The Effective Floating Volume (EFV) developed under this grant represents a powerful novel method to simulate multi-physics multi-scale problems in various scientific and technical fields. As a mesh-free method, it is straightforward to implement it in parallel computer platforms, taking full advantage of highly parallelized computing environments such as GPUs.

The EFV-MCM simulation technology developed under this grant can potentially have a significant impact on several engineering, scientific and technical applications where full-scale problems and transient simulations are impractical with currently existing tools, namely:

  • Design and simulation of superconducting devices.
  • Quench analysis in superconducting devices.
  • Simulation of heat transfer in porous media, metal hydride heat pumps, particle bed heat exchangers.
  • Simulation and design optimization to minimize flaw formation in additive manufacturing: Laser Powder Bed Fusion or Directed Energy Deposition.
  • Design and analysis of eddy current losses in electromagnetic coils (or current carrying conductors) of complex geometry. 
  • Design and optimization of electrical machines for optimal efficiency and power density
